Architecture in Three Dimensions

Architecture is art we live in. It helps define our culture. It evolves over time. It tells a story of human creation and it is having a profound effect on our environment. Join us to explore how architecture influences our lives in a showcase of scale models, highlighting architectural design from around the world, by the Canadian Museum of Architecture.

Union Summer presented by TD - Best of Union Beats: DJ Sarabi

We’re bringing our favourite DJ’s from our indoor Union Beats program to the patio!

Union Summer – presented by TD returns to the plaza in front of Union Station from June 25th – August 10th, 2025, for its 8th edition! Union Station is THE destination for all to enjoy the best of Toronto’s food and culture. This market offers 47-days of free outdoor experiences featuring dynamic music, live performances, curated food vendors and beat-the-heat beverages and desserts, all to celebrate summer in the city.

Get your weekend groove on early, or take your work to the patio for some tunes.

DJ SARABI is a DJ and producer specializing in Afrobeats, Amapiano, House, & Soulful Global Vibes. DJ SARABI is also a classically trained pianist and vocalist. DJ SARABI has played for small and large audiences globally, including in Rwanda, Kenya, the Middle East, and across Canada. DJ SARABI is a lawyer by day, and DJ by night. She looks forward to jamming with you! Visit www.djsarabi.com for music, mixes and more.

https://djsarabi.bandcamp.com

FREEUP! Emancipation Day 2025

Join us for FREEUP! Emancipation Day 2025—a powerful, live celebration of freedom, creativity, and community, hosted by Emancipation Arts and cultural curator Ngozi Paul.

This free, family-friendly event features an incredible lineup of live music, dance, art, and interactive experiences, all rooted in the spirit of Emancipation Day.

🌟 Highlights Include:

The Recipee Band

Charmie Deller

DJ MelBoogie

RAP SHEETS Trivia with DJ Nana & North English

Dance Demos: Soca with Michael Mortley + African Dance with ZahraMoves

Live Painting by Adrian Hayles

Rosemary Sadlier Freedom Award Presentation honouring Djanet Sears

Free Massages & Kids Face Painting!

From soul-stirring performances to joy-filled movement, community pride, and cultural excellence—FREEUP! is where we honour our past and move boldly into the future.

Admission is FREE. All are welcome—come solo, with friends, or bring the whole family!

First come, first served for wellness and interactive stations.

Miss Likklemore's Chef Collab Dinner Series

Leading up to Toronto Caribbean Carnival, Miss Likklemore's partnered with Chef Marc Kusitor to bring elevated Haitian cuisine to life inside our kitchen. Join us for a one night only experience showcasing caribbean culture, flavour and hospitality with Chef Marc's flavourful 4 course menu, including a welcome cocktail and menu introduction by the chef himself.

Welcome Cocktail

First

Croquette

legim-stuffed croquette, coconut crème fraîche, pikliz

Second

Pwason Gros Sel

black cod, glazed ground provisions, beurre blanc lakay, scotch bonnet oil

Third

Oxtail

djon djon oxtail gravy, carnaroli rice, green epis

Fourth

Kokiyol

donut, Haitian coffee crème pâtissière, vanilla sugar

Presented by Grace Food Company and Omi Wood

All reservations will be included in a draw to win a collection piece from Omi Woods Jewelery - which celebrate Island and Africana culture. Omi Woods jewelry is intended to be collected, worn everyday, gifted for special occasions and passed down to future generations so its meaning can live on for generations to come.

Comedy on the River - A Unique Paddle-in Comedy Show!

Come Enjoy our Comedy On The River show on August 1st!

To book your spot, please go to the link:

https://torontoadventures.ca/all-adventures/comedy-shows-on-the-river/

Link will show live boat availability and options!

Kayak or Canoe or Standup Paddle Board your way to a Comedy show right on the Humber River!

Located on Toronto’s beautiful Humber River our Comedy On The River event starts at our Humber Paddling center (only a 5-Minute walk from Old Mill TTC Station)! Upon arrival, we’ll get you checked in and set you up with your boat and equipment before you embark on your scenic paddle of the meandering Humber River to the stage right along the river! Upon arrival, you’ll be greeted by host Dan Galea and some of Toronto’s biggest upcoming comedians.

Pricing (per boat), Payable online through:

https://torontoadventures.ca/all-adventures/comedy-shows-on-the-river/

Single Kayak (seats 1 person) : $40 +taxes

Tandem Kayak (seats 2 people) : $80 +taxes

Regular Canoe (seats 2 people) : $70 +taxes

Large Canoe (seats 3 people) : $90 +taxes

Stand Up Paddleboard (1 person) : $45 +taxes

Voyageur Canoe Seat (1 person): $40 +taxes

Bring Your Own Boat (boat/equipment): $10 +taxes

What's Included:

Boat(s)

Paddle(s)

PFD(s) “Lifejackets”

Comedy show right on the river!

Our experienced staff to help you every step of the way!

What to Bring:

Dress for the weather!

Sunscreen, Sunglasses & Hats, are all recommended for sunny days!

Blanket to keep you cozy during the show.

Important Information:

Check specific event dates for start time and duration!

Anyone under 18 must be accompanied by an adult or legal guardian.

Cancellation & Weather

*Events are subject to weather and other factors out of our control. Any weather cancellations will be announced through email to booked attendees and on the home page of www.TorontoAdventures.ca.*

Click Here to view our Cancellations & Rescheduling Policy:

https://www.torontoadventures.ca/cancellation-rescheduling/

Too Much Fashion - An Ode to Black Creative Resilience

United Contemporary is proud to present “Too Much Fashion”, a powerful group exhibition that celebrates Black cultural influence, creative resilience, and the enduring intersections between fashion and art across the Black diaspora. Together, nine black artists create a textured narrative that recognizes fashion not only as clothing or ornamentation, but as a profound mode of storytelling, cultural assertion, and survival.

- Gordon Shadrach reframes historical portraiture to challenge dominant narratives of Black masculinity.

- Benny Bing paints commanding portraits that centre the dignity and complexity of Black identity through vivid colour and form.

- Veronica Dorsett is a visual artist whose practice encompasses a wide range of materials that focuses a critical lens on Black hair politics and adolescence.

- Ojo Agi renders delicate, emotive figures on brown paper, celebrating the nuances of Black skin and care rituals.

- Ehiko Odeh transforms everyday Black hair products into monumental paintings that reassert presence and pride.

- Kachelle Knowles explores the ideas of gender identity, cultural preservation, production, and social relations within the black community.

- Janice Reid captures expansive photographic portraits across the Caribbean and North America, offering liberatory representations of Black trans, cis, and non-binary individuals.

- Kriss Munsya focuses on the role of race and gender in the construction of identity and memory through an expanded photographic practice.

- Adetona Omokanye is a photojournalist and visual artist whose work captures the richness and complexity of African cultures through a distinct visual lens.

Co-curated by Byron Armstrong and Ilene Sova of Armova Curatorial, this timely exhibition opens to the public on Friday, August 1, 2025, with a celebratory reception, aligning with Emancipation Month and the Toronto Carnival—two significant events that honour Black freedom, identity, and joy.

(Image credit: Kriss Munsya, Even, Genetic Bomb, 2022)

The Art of the Butcher and the Chef

To mark the start of Cameron Taylor's butchery-centric catering company, his event is taking place at Rily Kitchen (26 Sousa Mendes St) on Friday, August 1st from 6-10pm. Guests will start with welcome cocktails, charcuterie, and Canadian oysters. The event will then feature an exclusive live butchery demonstration of beef rib and loin, showcasing the skill and precision involved. Following the demonstration, guests will enjoy a gourmet five-course sit-down meal featuring the freshly prepared cuts and paired with a selection of wines and beers. Additionally, guests will have an opportunity to purchase the meat from the demonstration. Tickets to attend are priced at $150 per guest and can be purchased on Eventbrite.

Union Summer presented by TD - Soul Fridays: Bana Onmarz

Soul Fridays bring the best Soul, RnB and other big bands to the TD Stage.

Union Summer – presented by TD returns to the plaza in front of Union Station from June 25th – August 10th, 2025, for its 8th edition! Union Station is THE destination for all to enjoy the best of Toronto’s food and culture. This market offers 47-days of free outdoor experiences featuring dynamic music, live performances, curated food vendors and beat-the-heat beverages and desserts, all to celebrate summer in the city.

Come ready to sing, dance and start your weekend off on the perfect note.

OnMarz Productions, renowned for its infectious fusion of Soca, Reggae, R&B, House, Rock, Gospel, and more. The dynamic musical captivates audiences worldwide, blending nostalgic throwbacks with contemporary hits. Whether igniting stages with electrifying performances or showcasing instrumental skill, OnMarz Productions exudes a profound passion for music. Embracing a diverse range of genres, the music resonates with a modern flair while honoring traditional roots. Prepare to groove to the unforgettable sounds of OnMarz Productions, where music seamlessly blends with timeless innovation.

Known for their lively and dynamic performances, the band consists of Omar Martin, Kirk Grange, Tre Taylor, Anthony Wisdom, Gyles, Nichelle Bernard, Kamil Andre and Jarelle, who have garnered a reputation with their contagious personalities and their ability to create a fun atmosphere wherever they play establishing themselves as some of the city’s premier artists. Come out and support them!

Insta: @omaronmarz

ShareTweet
Union Station

Free First Friday Night Performance: Stephanie Chua and Allison Cameron

Presented within Margaux Williamson's “Shoes, Books, Hands, Buildings, and Cars” at MOCA, this live performance investigates surface, perception, and the present moment in dialogue with the exhibition.

The evening opens as pianist Stephanie Chua performs Morton Feldman’s “For Bunita Marcus,” a 75-minute solo work renowned for its quiet intensity and spacious beauty. As the final notes dissipate, composer and sound artist Allison Cameron joins Chua in an improvised soundscape that responds intimately to Williamson’s paintings.

Together, Chua and Cameron mirror Williamson’s layered visual compositions, where everyday objects and multiple perspectives coexist. Drawing from Feldman’s resonant, durational style, their performance extends this sensibility into the physical realm, sounding the inside of the piano to create a tactile, immersive sonic experience.

This performance is part of MOCA’s Free First Friday Nights. Admission is Free from 5–9 pm. Tickets can be obtained ahead of time or at the door. Book in advance to reserve your spot!

Zoukotop Caribana Edition at Mossops Social House

🎉 ZOUKOTOP – Caribbean Carnival Edition

📍 August 1 • Caribana Friday • Toronto

We’re taking the vibes up a notch.

After a sizzling June session, ZOUKOTOP returns for its 4th electrifying edition—and this time, we’re diving deep into the heart of Caribana for a night that captures the full rhythm and soul of ALL the Caribbean carnival culture.

Join us Friday, August 1st at Mossop Social Club, where the energy flows from the dancefloor straight to your spirit. Expect the hottest beats in Dancehall, Bouyon, Soca, Afrobeats and, of course, your usual Zouk and Konpa sessions.

💃🏽✨ Whether you’re coming to show your move or stepping in just to soak up the vibes, we got you !

this night promises vibrant colors, joyful movement, delicious cocktails, and a crowd that knows how to fête.

🎶 Dj MisteuRing and Dj Has are back at it again, blending infectious rhythms and carnival heat to keep your waistline moving from start to finish.

This is more than a party—it’s a statement. It’s unity, culture, and pure celebration of ALL the Caribbean.

Music start at 6:30 PM until 11:30PM.

Photo booth and a welcome cocktail on us !

Ready to jump in? 💥

Introducing Fluid Bears to Artbox. You’ll explore vibrant colors and paint pouring techniques to craft a unique piece. Watch as paint flows and blends across the surface, creating mesmerizing, one-of-a-kind designs to each white bear.

Fluid Bears are being offered as an option to our Acrylic Paint Pouring and Glow-in-the-Dark Paint Pouring workshops. Just select it during the checkout process.

White Bear – A white bear made of resin with moveable limbs, that's ready to paint. (Size 23cm/9in)

Pouring Mediums – For smooth or bubbly patterns.​

Basic Tools – Everything needed to pour, swirl, and create!

Duel Citizens

Proudly celebrating 52 years in Toronto, The Second City presents their 90th Mainstage revue! Duel Citizens is a fast-paced comedy spectacle stacked with razor-sharp satire, hilarious songs, ridiculous characters and, of course, the signature improv comedy that The Second City is world famous for. Written and performed by a completely Canadian cast and crew, this show joyfully skewers politics, pop culture, and everything in between. From full-blown national tantrums to the absurdities of daily life, come laugh with The Second City as we turn chaos into comedy.

Theatre In St James Presents: The Tragedie of Romeo & Juliet

Pay what you can. No ticket required. Join us in St James Park, 120 King Street E, on and around the Michael Comstock Pavilion for Theatre In St. James Park.

Written by William Shakespeare

Directed by Nicholas Koy Santillo

Four Actors.

Two Households.

One Absolute Banger.

What was Shakespeare before stage lights, microphones and the Fourth Wall? Before he was revered and canonized, Shakespeare's plays were raucous, irreverent and relevant. When first staged in 1596, Romeo and Juliet referenced contemporary politics and the eternal human condition.

Much has changed since the 16th century, yet The Tragedie of Romeo and Juliet remains poignant and powerful — an autocratic Prince, an optimistic proselytizer, a loving nurse, and two star-crossed lovers.

This summer, whether you're in Verona or Toronto, one thing is certain: The day is hot, the Capulets abroad.

PERFORMANCE DATES & TIMES

Fri Aug 1 2025, 7pm-8pm

Sat Aug 2 2025, 7pm-8pm

Toronto Panorama - Keeping Pan Alive

Toronto Panorama Set to Ignite Lamport Stadium on Emancipation Day! 🥁

Toronto Panorama 2025 is bringing the heat to Lamport Stadium this Friday, August 1st, and trust us - you don’t want to miss this! Whether you're a die-hard fan, a Carnival junkie or just looking for something unforgettable to do on Emancipation Day, this is the event that will set your summer ablaze.

🔥 Ever wanted to see Toronto’s top steelbands go head-to-head in a no-holds-barred battle for bragging rights, supremacy and sweet, sweet steelpan glory? Panorama is where it all goes down. Expect thunderous rhythm sections, electrifying arrangements and vibes that'll have you dancing from the stands to the stage.

🌴 More than just a competition, Toronto Panorama is a powerful celebration of Caribbean culture, resilience, and freedom - marking Emancipation Day with music born from resistance and raised in joy.

✨ New this year! Kids 12 and under enter FREE once accompanied by a paying adult - so bring the whole family to experience the magic of pan under the stars.

📍 Lamport Stadium

🗓 Friday, August 1, 2025

🎟 Tickets available now: https://www.ticketgateway.com/event/view/toronto-panorama-2025-keeping-pan-alive

Come lime with us, wave your flag and feel the beat of emancipation echo through every note.

Josh Gondelman LIVE in Toronto!

Josh Gondelman is a writer and comedian who incubated in Boston before moving to New York City, where he currently lives and recently worked as the head writer and an executive producer for Desus & Mero on Showtime. Gondelman also contributed to the final season of The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel, which was a thrill for both him and his parents.

Prior to that, he spent five years at Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, first as a web producer and then as a staff writer where he earned four Emmy Awards, two Peabody Awards, and three WGA Awards.

His debut standup special People Pleaser (2022) was produced by Comedy Dynamics and is available to stream now.

If his face seems familiar, you may recognize it from his appearances on Conan (TBS), Late Night With Seth Meyers (NBC), and The Late Late Show with James Corden (CBS).

Cringey 2010's Music Trivia & Dance Party

Cringey 2010's Music Trivia is coming to The Rec Room... hosted by Quizmaster Jess! Followed by a DANCE PARTY!

Cause when I leave for the night (for trivia) I ain't coming back... the 2010's put out some BANGERS. Were they cringey? Looking back... yes... but we do know every word? We'll find out at TRIVIA!

TOP 3 TEAMS WIN A $100 REC ROOM GIFT CARD

2010's attire is encouraged ;)

MUSIC CLIPS with every question!

Location: The Rec Room, 255 Bremner Blvd

TRIVIA

Time: Doors open 6:00pm, first question 7:00pm

$15 Trivia ticket (inlcudes Trivia & Dance Party) (+tax & eventbrite fees)

DANCE PARTY

Time: 10pm kick-off

$8 Ticket (Dance Party only)(+tax & eventbrite fees)$12 cash at door

How to register for TRIVIA:

Grab your $15 ticket on eventbrite

After you register & pay, you will be prompted to input your team name

Ensure everyone on your team signs up with the same team name, and you will be sat together

Reserving your ticket secures you a reservation at The Rec Room

How to register for the Community Table or attend solo:

If you are looking to meet new people and join a new team, please put "Community" under the team name prompt

You will be sat at our Community Table, where other individuals or smaller groups signed up happy to meet new people!

You can sign up for a community table with a friend or two, or solo!

Trivia details:

Questions include name the album, artist, song title, movie/tv show, and FINISH THE LYRIC

Team size is recommended 1-6 people. If you'd like to play with a larger team, 1 point per additional player over 6 will be deducted from your score.

Top 3 teams win a $100 Rec Room giftcard!

Meet your host:

Meet Quizmaster Jess! She's been hosting themed trivia nights for 7 years in Toronto and is such a vibe. She specializes in highly competitive and fun trivia evenings!

Follow her on instagram: @quizmasterjess

SEE YOU THERE!

ShareTweet

Premium Desi Comedy Show !

At the Premium Desi Comedy Show you get stand-up comedy, magic acts, improv show and surprise acts - - all packed into one memorable desi entertainment evening 💥

Our 1st show was a super sell-out with 80 audience members! So we are putting 2 show times for you to choose from - 7 pm and 9 pm. When you click 'get tickets' you will have the option to choose your show time.

This is Toronto's one of its kind Desi Comedy Show which features a diverse line-up of artists who will take you from giggles to amazement and back! Be ready to laugh your hearts out with us at the Desi Food Junction on Fri Aug 01 2025 at 7 PM and 9 PM. Both the shows have an amazing line-up of artists, choose the time slot when your energies are at their highest 👯

You will get to see the best Desi (South Asian) comics who have performed all over the world. Get ready for a mix of bollywood, relationships, cricket, career and a diverse genres of jokes 🤣

Line-up for 7 pm show:

Dhama | @therealdhama

Tarun | @sudhar_ja_tarun

Saumya | @saumya_pahwa

Hershawn | @rapsandlaughs

Aman | @amanur

Mohammad | @mo.abdullah____

Karine | @karinekazan

Gambit Magician | @gambitmagician

Surprise Acts!

Line-up for 9 pm show:

Dhama | @therealdhama

Hassan | @hassanbollywoodstar

Sana Khan | @sanakhanniazi_

Adi | @adiism_

Omair | @omair_supernerd

Siddesh | @siddeshpai

Cleo | @cyborgcleo

Sachin and Shreya | Two2Mango

Gambit Magician | @gambitmagician

Surprise Acts!

And there is more 😊

You get to savor amazing variety of Desi snacks and food items!

There is a full bar serving juices, alcoholic drinks, coffee and more

The venue can't be better than this! newest desi comedy stage in GTA.

Come join us for an amazing evening and grab the early bird discount before it sells out 🎁🎉

Please note that the venue does not allow outside food and drinks. Thanks for your understanding!

Paint and SIP: A Midsummer's Night Dream

Join us for paint night at Toronto’s newest paint studio – My Inner Child Paint Bar. Our paint and sip classes encourage you to explore your Inner Artist whether you’re an experienced painter or haven’t picked up a paint brush since elementary school. We promise a fun-filled evening of artistic expression, drink, and music in a relaxed atmosphere. Owner/artist, Claire, at My Inner Child believes that everyone can paint as we all used to do when we were little, we just need to tap into our INNER CHILD. Art is fun. Art is expressive. Art is creative. Art is healing.

Our paint nites are ideal for date night, girl’s night out and anyone looking to try something different.

The class is expected to take about 2.5 hours to complete, however, we guarantee extra studio time to allow you to put the final touches on your masterpiece.

We are conveniently located in mid-town Toronto, at 2725 Yonge Street north of Eglinton. There is plenty of cheap parking underground in the building as well as ample street parking.

The Chapel Choir of Pembroke College, Cambridge with Anna Lapwood

The Church of St. Mary Magdalene, Toronto, is delighted to host the Chapel Choir of Pembroke College, Cambridge, UK, and their director Anna Lapwood for an evening concert on Friday, August 1, 7:30 pm. Free General Admission Tickets are available here. Seating is first-come, first-served. (Suggested donation $40 at the door.)

Please plan to show your tickets to our ushers at the door. Doors will open for General Admission at 6:45 pm. The concert is scheduled to begin at 7:30 pm. We strongly encourage you to arrive as early as possible. There are a variety of public transportation options nearby and the surrounding neighborhood is easily accessible by bicycle or by walking. Bikes may be locked in the bike rack on the Ulster Street side of the building. There is very limited street parking available near the church. The church is fully wheelchair accessible.

The program will include an expansive range of works by Lucy Walker, Elanor Daley, Jonathan Dove, Eric Whitacre, Bob Dylan, and more. Recordings of some of these pieces may be heard on Lapwood’s recent album Firedove (Sony Classical 2025) and All Things Are Quite Silent (Sept 2020) by the Choirs of Pembroke College, Cambridge.

Spirited Away: Live on Stage

Hayao Miyazaki’s Academy Award-winning animated feature film comes to life in this first-ever stage adaptation, full of dazzling sets, captivating musical numbers and wondrous puppets portraying beloved characters. Adapted and directed by Tony Award winner John Caird (Les Misérables), two performances featuring unique casts were filmed during the show’s acclaimed 2022 run at Tokyo’s historic Imperial Theatre, featuring Kanna Hashimoto and Mone Kamishiraishi as Chihiro.

In Japanese, with English subtitles.

Every show is uniquely special because we bring different guest comedians to each performance! Our stage has hosted comedians who have shone at renowned festivals like Just for Laughs, and can be seen on platforms such Disney+, Apple TV, CBC, Netflix, and many more.

Tickets: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/all-of-us-are-minorities-tickets-743748500787?aff=oddtdtcreator

Hamburger LIVE in Toronto!

Born and raised in Elizabeth, New Jersey, Alonzo Hamburger Jones is an iconic comedian who first gained national attention in the nineties following appearances on HBO’s Def Comedy Jam.

He’s also appeared on Showtime at the Apollo, BET’s ComicView, Apollo Comedy Hour and Bryon Allen’s Comics Unleashed.

More recently, Hamburger has been parodied on Saturday Night Live and the animated series, Family Guy.

Pub Crawl Toronto

THE BEST PUB CRAWL IN TORONTO

Awarded the Badge of Excellence from TripAdvisor as the best pub crawl in the city 🏅

Featured on BlogTO as one of the best ways to meet people in Toronto 🤩

and…

Drink deals! 🎉🎉🎉

Party with fun people! 😍😍😍

We're headed to 3 really fun amazing spots on College Street, one of the funnest, coolest neighbourhoods in Toronto! See you there!

MEETING POINT

Track & Field, 582 College St.

When you get to the bar, ask a bartender where the pub crawl is (i.e. us) and they will direct you.

PARTY AGENDA

➡️ 9pm-10pm- Mingling with the Pub Crawl at our first bar of the night! Plus a free welcome shot, exclusive to Pub Crawl Toronto guests!

➡️ 10pm-11pm- Fun times at the 2nd stop of the night!

➡️ 11pm-Close- Party the rest of the night away at our 3rd and final stop of the night, a nightclub to dance the night away to awesome music! You get FREE ENTRY to the club too! Nice!

HOW WE’RE DIFFERENT (And the best, in our opinion! 😀😀)

➡️ Our prices will not increase between now and the pub crawl

➡️ Real drink specials exclusive to Pub Crawl Toronto- these are deals you won't get without a ticket to the crawl!

➡️ We don’t ditch pub crawlers at the door of the first stop of the night. Our host will be guiding the crawl throughout, to help ensure everyone has an amazing time!

➡️ Everyone moves together on the crawl, making it a great and easy way to meet everyone!

LOGISTICAL DETAILS

➡️ Can't find us? DM 647-746-3723 for help!

➡️ Every bar/club we are going to is less than 5 mins walking from the next one. So don’t worry about needing to walk any sort of long distance.

➡️ Make sure to come early so you can socialize with the group before things get crazy!

Learn more about us at pubcrawltoronto.com!

Living On Video Presents

Friday August 1 - INDIE FRIDAYS Video Dance Party

INDIE / ALTERNATIVE / THROWBACKS

TV ON THE RADIO After Party

Hosted plus DJ set by BOB of INDIE88.

BUY TIX $10: https://indiefridaysaug1.eventbrite.ca

There has never been an INDIE dance night like this is Toronto. Indie and Alternative from fresh cuts to classics with beautifully remastered music videos. This is the ONLY Indie / Alternative Video Dance Party in Canada.

Ground Control is an independent music venue inspired by David Bowie and the ONLY music video dance bar in Canada. There are 6 large screens around the venue projecting awesome videos for your dancing pleasure. The screens are also interactive and allow text shoutouts, requests, and party photos to be posted for all to see.

Join us EVERY Friday for INDIE FRIDAYS.

The 2000s Party - Caribana Edition

This Caribana Friday, Toronto’s nightlife scene takes a time machine back to the golden era — the 2000s.

Join us for the ultimate throwback celebration with The 2000s Party: Yonge Street Edition — a nostalgic experience bringing together fashion, music, and energy inspired by the iconic Yonge Street vibes.

🎧 DJ Lineup

@mydj2nice x @kamakacci_juice x @leezyboysr x @bookdjdk

Special Guest from NYC: @djsuperstarjay 🇺🇸

More surprise guests TBA.

🍹 Sponsored by @1800tequila

👕 Come drippin’ in your freshest 2000s look — airbrush tees, Avirex jackets, G-Unit gear, Sidekicks, Baby Phat, Rocawear — we’re bringing back the era of CD players and Big Slice pizza runs.

🎶 Expect the sounds of Ludacris, 50 Cent, Missy, Dipset, and more — this isn’t just a party, it’s a cultural moment.

We have a strict code of conduct and reserve the right to refuse anyone at any time. Wiggle Room is a Safer Dance Space. We take this very seriously. We encourage everyone to bring to our attention anything they think we should be made aware of, such as harassment, violation of personal space, solicitation, or use of controlled substances, over-intoxicated behaviour, or anything else that may pose a risk or discomfort to you or others. You may use the safe word BANANA, ask any of our staff for a Banana, and we will direct you to a safe, quiet space. Our security staff are in marked clothing. Our team and event hosts, such as Takin, Lindsay Fay, Nour Bawab, Christina Barron, Tyler Hill, Monique, Mitch (lead security), and Tanya, are all available.

KLEAN: CARIBANA NIGHT PARTY

On Aug 1, it's Caribana 2025: KLEAN – Night Party

Dress fresh. Move wild. KLEAN is where style meets Soca for a night of pure energy and elegant chaos.

With Soca, Dancehall, and Afrobeat setting the pace, this party is built for the bold—high heat, heavy riddims, and a crowd that came to shell in style. From start to finish, it's nothing but clean fits, dirty wines, and nonstop movement.

10PM Friday - Pro & Hilarious Late-Night Comedy Laugh - Guaranteed Hilarity

Friday Comedy Showcase of Toronto's best comedians

Elevate your Friday nights with the city's comedy elite! Join us at 10 PM for a hilarious showcase at Backroom Comedy Club. Experience top-tier stand-up, guaranteed laughs, and an unforgettable start to the weekend. Reserve your spot now for a night of comedic brilliance and good times!

2025 Summer Art Camp at Palette Art School

During our exciting 5-day camp week, students will dabble in the arts and create a variety of lovely artwork. Students will have the chance to work in different media (graphite, paint and clay, for example) to create sketches, drawings, paintings and even sculptures alongside our amazing staff.

Our experienced instructors will guide camp students through the creative process and help each child learn, create wonderful art, and have fun. Our camp intructors have many years of experience with young artists, enabling them to create the most engaging, fun and educational experience for your child.

24th Annual Globehead Comedy Tournament

GLOBEHEAD is Bad Dog’s annual short form improv tournament, and is now in its 24th year. Globehead is a hotly-contested Toronto comedy tradition and this year's lineup is packed with an incredible mix of veteran heavy-hitters, emerging comedy powerhouses, and “celebrity” judges - you never know who you might see!

Hosted by Ryan Sheedy and Sarah Hillier

Fridays in July and August at 7pm

July 4, 11, 18, 25, August 1, 8, 15, 22, 29

Comedy Bar Bloor (945 Bloor St. W.)

$15 online, $20 at the door, PWYC available

38th Annual Ward's Island Fire Parade

Presented by Shadowland Theatre

All Creatures Great and Small

FREE Workshops and Events: July 26 to August 1

Fire Parade: Friday, August 1, 8:30pm

Come enjoy Toronto’s best FREE arts-filled summer event in the City’s most beautiful park!

Join Shadowland Theatre for our annual community arts residency and performance on the beautiful Ward’s Island, situated in the Toronto Island Park. Shadowland presents a fun-filled week of art-making workshops, music and performance activities.

From July 26 to August 1, Shadowland welcomes artists and community members to join together over the residency week to create lanterns, puppets, costumes and more. All-ages and abilities are welcome.

On August 1, at 8:30pm participants, artists and community will come together for 38th Annual Ward’s Island Fire Parade, a magical celebration of light and community.

More information and to register for free workshops:

https://www.shadowlandtheatre.ca/fireparade2025

Ferry Schedule to Ward's Island:

https://www.toronto.ca/explore-enjoy/parks-recreation/places-spaces/beaches-gardens-attractions/toronto-island-park/all-ferry-schedules/

8PM Friday Pro & Hilarious Stand-up - Comedy Kickoff & Laughs guaranteed

Get groovy with Funky Fridays! Toronto's comedy party starts at 8 PM. Unwind, laugh, and kick off your weekend in style!

Dive into the comedic groove every Friday at 8 PM! Experience the funky vibes of Toronto's top comedians at Backroom Comedy Club. Join us for a night of uproarious laughter, good times, and the perfect start to your weekend. Secure your spot for an unforgettable evening filled with funky fun and stand-up brilliance!

Aburi TORA launches Summer features menu in collaboration MICHELIN-star chef Ryusuke Nakagawa

North York’s Aburi TORA has launched an exclusive summer lineup showcasing refined ingredients and eye-catching presentation. Led by Head Chef Young Son, the menu features indulgent new additions, including a standout collaboration with MICHELIN-starred chef Ryusuke Nakagawa of Aburi Hana. Perfect for a casual lunch or refined dinner outing, the updated offerings highlight summer’s finest flavours with an Aburi twist, complete with a playful parfait to finish. The menu is available exclusively for dine-in service. Reservations can be made HERE from 12 pm to 5 pm.

Summer feature menu Highlights

O-Toro Caviar Gunkan ($8.50)

Collaboration dish with MICHELIN Chef Ryusuke Nakagawa made with bluefin, caviar, truffle, kimizu and hanaho

Botan Ebi ($9)

Spot prawn with crispy fried head

Vanilla Strawberry Parfait ($6)

Vanilla ice cream, strawberry mochi, strawberry mousse, whipped creamMatcha Parfait – Earthy matcha ice cream, soft mochi, sweet azuki beans, whipped cream

Chestnut Mont Blanc ($9)

Chestnut cream piped over sponge, topped with a whole chestnut and a dusting of icing sugar

A Comedy Show - F'ckin' Funny Friday @ 7 & 8:30

There’s no funnier weekly comedy show than F*ckin’ Funny Friday at Toronto's #1 Black/Queer-owned comedy club! With 2 shows at 7:00 & 8:30 PM and discount tickets for couples and groups this is the show for you. Laugh so hard that you get a six-pack every Friday. Let's laugh, drink, and maybe even win this Friday!

F*ckin' Funny Friday is our weekly showcase of the comics that you should know. These people are going places. Be the kool kids and see them before they’re famous!

We stack the lineup with pros (getting ready for a tour, TV, moving out of mom's basement) and up 'n' coming stars (newbies still in mom's basement).

F*ckin’ Funny Friday is perfect for date nights, bachelor/ette parties, a nice night with mom, and team building.

First date? Let us do the talking for you. Whether your 1st date or 100th your chances of getting laid are higher when you laugh together. It's science.

See comics featured on Just For Laughs, JFL Toronto, CBC Comedy, Sirius XM, and more.

The Comedy Lab is Toronto’s only minority-owned comedy club. Check out the home of Canada’s most eclectic lineups of killer comedians in the city. Celebrate the diversity that makes the Canadian comedy scene.

A Glow-in-the-dark Paint Night by Artbox

Welcome to Artbox's Glow in the Dark Paint Night! An Artistic, Sensory Experience like no other.

What to Expect: When you arrive, take a moment to admire the first floor gallery and immerse yourself in the artistic atmosphere. Grab a complimentary snack and beverage before you head down to our glowing art studio, filled with more art, abstract projections and a curated playlist to set the vibe.

Guidance: Follow along with a trained artist and instructor, to paint a glowing scene sure to spark your senses with each brush stroke. You'll be guided step-by-step and also encouraged to add your own creative touches to your piece. During the workshop, guests are able to call on the instructor if they need help with anything. The end is flexible for those who need a little extra time to work on their piece.

Materials: You'll be equipped with an apron, 11X14” canvas, paints and all necessary supplies to create a glowing piece of art. We'll be working with acrylic neon paints that glow in our UV light studio and at the end, participants can go in with glow in the dark paint to add elements that can glow at home too.

Snacks & Refreshments: Enjoy from a selection of refreshments, tea/coffee and snacks all included with your ticket.

Who Should Join: Connect with fellow creatives in a unique and inspiring setting. Not sure if you’re creative? If you come to this paint night, consider yourself creative. Perfect for beginners and seasoned artists alike, this event offers an artistic, immersive experience for all. Let your inner artist out in a serene and supportive environment at Artbox Studio Gallery.

Must be aged 10+ to participate. Ages 16 and under require 1 paying 18+ adult for every 2 youth. Some age exceptions can be made upon request. Please call to inquire (416)690-9550.

No experience needed!

Click to see our glow paint sessions: https://www.artboxstudiogallery.com/glow-in-the-dark-paint

Arcadia Earth Toronto

Arcadia Earth is a large-scale multi-sensory journey through planet Earth that combines creative art installations and exciting technology to inspire visitors to take action towards a more sustainable future. In a stunning 10-room adventure, enhanced by interactive projection mapping, augmented reality and virtual reality, the immersive experience showcases the beauty of our planet and the impact of human actions on the environment. The experience is educational, inspiring, fun and great for all ages!

Architecture Camp

Toronto Metropolitan University Department of Architectural Science presents this week-long camp for campers looking to unleash their creativity! Campers learn from some of the top Architectural Science students at Toronto Metropolitan, and participate in innovative and engaging team and individual exercises.

Each week's program culminates in a distinct take-home project that campers develop and take home on the final day of the week.

Camp days comprise an even balance of Architecture programming and physically active Camp games, so your camper goes home each day having nurtured both their body and brain.

The curriculum for Architecture Camp is developed by Prof. Vince Hui, who is a past recipient of the Ontario Confederation of University Faculty Associations Teacher Award.

Arts in the Parks: Park in Motion

Park in Motion is a family-friendly outdoor dance performance series by MillO Dance Projects. Through performances and interactive activities, Park In Motion aims to celebrate diversity and foster a vibrant and inclusive space to connect with and bring together the community.

 

This year, we are showcasing two 15-minute contemporary dance works: Colours, choreographed and performed by MillO Dance Projects, and To My Past…, choreographed and performed by Nickeshia Garrick. Themes of home, connection, and self-discovery flow through contemporary dance, improvisation, and vocal work. Toward the end of the performance, there will be a 10-minute interactive segment featuring guided vocalization and gentle movement practice, designed to be accessible for people of all ages and abilities.

October 3, 2024 – March 23, 2026
Report Inaccuracy

Art/Wear: Sneakers x Artists

“What is art?” This question has sparked debate for centuries, and today, the boundaries of what defines art are being pushed further than ever. One significant shift is the growing trend of artists engaging in commercial collaborations, particularly with sneaker brands. These collaborations blur the lines between art, fashion, and commerce, offering consumers the opportunity to buy and wear creations by some of the most revered figures in the art world. Many of these sneakers are also finding their place within traditional art spaces, such as museums and auction houses, where their rarity has elevated them to a status similar to limited edition artist prints. The cultural significance of these artist-sneaker collaborations is contributing to the ongoing discussion of what defines art today.

Many artists are increasingly using sneakers in conceptually rich ways to challenge and redefine conventional artistic boundaries. By manipulating the familiar form of sneakers, these artists create provocative works that explore themes of consumerism, personal expression, and societal expectations. Through their deconstruction, repurposing, and political use of sneakers, these artists invite viewers to reconsider the intersections between art, fashion, and identity in the modern world.

Art/Wear: Sneakers and Artists asks why artists are drawn to working on/with sneakers and why so many of us are interested in wearing these pieces. It also explores the longstanding divide in Western thought between art and fashion, ultimately questioning if and how our collective definitions of art are shifting. Topics explored include: a history of sneakers as canvases, graffiti artists and sneakers, and artist collabs, and the rise of customization as its own art form.

Artists on view: Aaron Fowler, Alife, Andrew Mania, Bryant Giles, Cey Adams, Damien Hirst, Daniel Arsham, Dave White, ESPO, Futura, Eric Haze, Hebru Brantley, Javier Calleja, Jean-Michel Basquiat, Judi Werthein, Kate Knudsen, KAWS, Keith Haring, Kenzo Minami, Mache, Michael Lau, MSCHF, Peter Max, Ruohan Wang, Shantell Martin, Stash, Takashi Murakami, Tom Sachs, Vicky Vuong, and Virgil Abloh.

A State of Balance: New Exhibition by Sheila Kernan Exploring Nature, Harmony, and the Creative Process at Bau-Xi Gallery Dufferin

Sheila Kernan’s upcoming exhibition, A State of Balance, is a powerful meditation on harmony, tension, and the quiet intelligence of nature. In this new body of work, Kernan invites viewers into richly layered compositions where visual opposites - soft and sharp, dense and airy, stillness and movement - are masterfully brought into alignment. Drawing inspiration from the ever-shifting rhythms of the natural world, particularly the landscapes of Muskoka and the Great Lakes, Kernan creates paintings that feel both grounded and alive. A State of Balance offers a space to pause, reflect, and contemplate the beauty and balance found in both nature and art.

The exhibition will be on view from July 10th - August 4th at Bau-Xi Gallery | Dufferin in Toronto (1384 Dufferin Street). An opening reception will take place on Saturday, July 12th from 2 - 5 pm with Sheila Kernan in attendance.

Artist statement:

“In this new collection, I strive to achieve a unique state of balance within each painting and throughout the series. Through careful manipulation of contrasting painted elements—such as soft and hard edges, thick textures and thin washes, foreground, and background elements, I engage in a constant process of editing and reworking until my intuitive sense of equilibrium has been attained. This pursuit of balance often requires multiple layers of paint, numerous techniques, a careful observant eye, intense concentration, and presence.

There is delicate reciprocity between each visual element. At times it can be harmonious, offering stability. At times it can be more dynamic, offering an interplay between opposing forces and ideas. The movement between both creates a sense of dynamism and tension, which becomes its own form of balance even if not static. All of which contribute to creating an eye-catching composition.

Nature is a prime example of dynamic balance; its constant state of flux is truly inspirational and why I enjoy mirroring it in my compositions. I value how nature provides a sanctuary for us, it fosters a sense of connection and well-being that contributes significantly to joy, happiness, and contentment. Nature has always been an underlying theme in my paintings, and I am particularly drawn to places that I have a personal connection with. My family’s roots in the east stretch back generations, and each time I visit, I feel a profound connection to the land especially Muskoka and the Great Lakes.

By sharing my process with you, I hope to provide some insight and to invite you to contemplate the beauty and balance found in both nature and art.” – Sheila Kernan

About Sheila Kernan:

Sheila Kernan is a Calgary-based artist who is known for her unique and tactile aesthetic. Her work oscillates between realism and abstraction, referencing memory and imagination. Her compositions are meticulously crafted through her use of referential collages made from multiple photographs and sketches. Intensely saturated colours, graphic forms and thick painterly strokes collide in multiple layers.

Sheila Kernan’s work can be found in numerous private, corporate, and public art collections across North America, Europe, Australia, and Africa. Having earned her B.F.A from the Alberta College of Art and Design (ACAD) in 2006, she has gone on to showcase her work nationally in more than 40 exhibitions. In 2017, she was awarded a lifetime achievement award as the recipient of the ACAD Alumni Legacy Award.

At Home in Toronto

At Home in Toronto

What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members, the exhibition invites you to explore the many ways we define, create, and carry home with us. From a World War One soldier’s return ticket home to a precious family object stewarded by multiple generations, you’ll encounter belongings, voices, and stories of Toronto artists, makers, entrepreneurs, and community leaders as they share their unique perspectives on belonging, identity, and place. These powerful objects offer fresh, heartfelt perspectives on what it means to find, make, or remember home.

At Home in Toronto includes the artworks of Rebecca Baird, Carl Beam, Fred Hagan, Robert Houle, Luis Jacob, Kit Li, Raoul Olou, Yasmine Louis, and Natalie Wood, as well as loaned works by Toronto artists Doug Brown and Frantz Brent-Harris.

The exhibition is open Wednesday to Sunday, 11 am to 5 pm. Please check www.toronto.ca/marketgallery for holiday closures and special extended hours. Free admission.

A Transit Through Time

The exhibition located in the West Wing is a co-curatorial project in collaboration with MakeRoom Inc. Union’s relationship with MakeRoom Inc was born out of a shared mission to create spaces for local artists that are inclusive, diverse and equitable. This year the call asked artists to respond to the following questions: What does culture mean to you? How do you honour the past?

The featured works of artists Destinie Adélakun, Pixel Heller, Segun Caezar, Heritier Bilaka, Rico Poku and Camille Kiffin encourage exploration of the connections between the past and present, and the traditions that have shaped culture through time. They offer a glimpse into the enduring legacy and boundless creativity of Black communities.

In addition to the group exhibition, Union has selected special guest artist Jordan Sook to present the solo exhibition, Nothing More Nothing Less, a collection of images of butterflies showcased in various mediums throughout Union for people to discover. The butterflies, containing the artist's signature hand painted spots, represent self-expression and the joyfulness of the human spirit. Each piece merges entomology with curiosity, exploring themes of metamorphosis, transformation and evolution.

Opening to the public on Wednesday, February 12, at 6pm with an artist panel and musical celebration. The exhibitions are open daily during station operating hours and are located on the ground level in the West Wing and Oak Room. Additionally, Jordan Sook’s works extend to the station’s exterior banners along Front Street, as well as digital screens and a hoarding wall in the new lower area of the station. Admission is free, and the exhibition runs until August 2025.

Report Inaccuracy

Auschwitz. Not long ago. Not far away.

The internationally touring exhibition, created by Musealia, co-produced by the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum in Poland, and developed with an esteemed international panel of curators and historians, is one of the most comprehensive exhibitions ever presented on the subject, and ROM is the only Canadian stop on its international tour. Survivor testimonials, historical documentation, and first-hand accounts by emancipating forces create a powerful connection to the exhibition's more than 500 original objects — many of which have never been seen before in Canada — on loan from the Auschwitz Memorial and more than 20 other major institutions and private collections around the world.

BBQ Party Fridays at Pogue Mahone

Your Fridays just found their flavour. Join us on the patio at Pogue Mahone every Friday for our BBQ Party Fridays — a laid-back evening of sizzling food, cool drinks, and all the sunshine (or good vibes indoors if it rains).

From 4 PM to 8 PM, we’re grilling your favourites and serving up a rotating menu of barbecue classics, cold beer, and summer cocktails. It's your new after-work ritual or pre-night-out warm-up — no ticket needed, just show up hungry.

🍔 What to Expect:

Grilled eats hot off the BBQ

Live DJ and great energy

Spacious patio seating (first come, first served)

Indoor backup for rainy days.

Table reservations highly recommended.

Where: Pogue Mahone Pub & Kitchen – 777 Bay St.

When: Fridays | 4 PM – 8 PM

☀️ Patio party. Rain or shine.

Below Our Feet and Above Our Heads Group Exhibition

Running from July 30th to August 17th at Propeller Art Gallery, the group exhibition Below Our Feet and Above Our Heads explores the merging of natural and artificial spheres.

Through a variety of mediums, including printmaking, painting, installation, animation, and performance, Below Our Feet and Above Our Heads features nine impactful artists: Vismay Sanghavi, Judith Librach, Timo Cheah, Raven Myers, Andria Keen, Deepikah R Bhardwaj, Seamus McVey Neufeld, Sari Cheah, and Daren Souvannavong. In-gallery sound provided by Zubin Isaac.

Campus Secrets and Spectres- University of Toronto Ghost Tour

Explore the majestic gothic architecture and picturesque tree-lined paths of the campus as we uncover its eerie history and spine-chilling ghostly tales. As we stroll through the historic grounds, our expert guides will captivate you with chilling stories of ghostly sightings and supernatural phenomena witnessed by students, faculty, and visitors alike. Whether you’re a history buff, a believer in the paranormal, a student or alum, or just looking for a unique and spooky evening experience in Toronto, our Campus Secrets & Spectres ghost tour will leave you with a sense of wonder and intrigue as we reveal the haunted secrets of the University of Toronto’s downtown campus.

Tickets available online at hauntedwalk.com or by calling our office at 416-238-1473

*Tour dates/times may vary throughout the season, please check our website to view the full tour schedule*

July 17 – August 30, 2025
Report Inaccuracy

Canadian Photographs: 1900 - 1950

Recent events have prompted citizens of Canada to reflect on our country’s significance. When we recall the places, events, and people that have shaped our collective memory, it is often photographs that come to mind. To support this reflection and inspire further appreciation, we have selected works from the gallery’s collection that highlight the important role photography plays in documenting history. This exhibition also offers an opportunity to recognize the contributions of Canadian photographers to the development of the medium.

This exhibition features photographs taken in Canada, as well as works created by Canadians elsewhere. Organized into thematic sections, the exhibition begins with images of Toronto as an emerging metropolis, followed by views of other regions across a span of fifty years. One section is dedicated to Canadian photographers working in the Pictorialist style, a movement that played a role in shifting photographic practices and paved the way toward Modernism. The final selection focusses on portraits of Canadians as well as photographs of events—both major and minor—that illustrate the era.

Canadian Stage presents the 42nd annual Dream in High Park - ROMEO & JULIET

Now celebrating 42 years of bringing Torontonians together for the beloved summer theatre tradition of Shakespeare under the stars, Canadian Stage is thrilled to present this year’s magical Dream in High Park production – the Bard’s most touching and romantic tragedy – ROMEO & JULIET, on stage in the enchanting High Park Amphitheatre from July 13th to August 31st.

One of Shakespeare’s most adored and enduring plays, ROMEO & JULIET is the greatest of love stories and romantic tragedies. Following the titular ill-fated lovers whose rival families, the Capulets and Montagues, are locked in a brutal blood feud, this most iconic work has captivated audiences and artists for centuries and been reimagined within countless films, ballets, operas, novels and more.

Pack a picnic, some pillows, and a cozy blanket, and head to High Park for Toronto's dreamiest date night.

Chinese Zodiac Case: Year of the Snake at ROM

As part of our annual zodiac installation, January 29, 2025 ushers in the Year of the Snake (蛇), the sixth animal in the Chinese zodiac. Those born under this sign are believed to be wise and charismatic.

The snake rarely appears as a decorative motif in Chinese art and design, however, when depicted with a tortoise, the pair have come to symbolize the mythical creature Xuanwu (玄武, the Dark Warrior), later evolving into the god Zhenwu (真武, the Perfected Warrior). The snake and tortoise symbolize the interplay of power, wisdom, and harmony of nature.

Experience an exquisite array of snake and tortoise-themed objects and cultural belongings in this specially curated zodiac case. Marvel at impressive ceramics, including a mythical double-headed serpent from the early 500s. This and much more are now on view in this unique display celebrating the powerful snake.

ShareTweetAdd to my Events
Royal Ontario Museum
100 Queen's Park Ave, Toronto ON

Clock Off at the Malibu Bar at Union Summer

Torontonians – are you craving a chance to swap work stress for sunshine? Well, Union Summer just got a sun-soaked upgrade where you can leave the work grind behind and do whatever tastes good. This summer, “clock off” at the Malibu Bar at Union Summer with three new Malibu cocktail offerings, Polar Ice slushies, and ready-to-drink cocktail cans!

Located on Front Street, just outside Union Station's main entrance, the Union Station Patio runs from now until August 10 and offers free outdoor experiences featuring music, live performances, food vendors, and beat-the-heat beverages and desserts. In the area? Why not make it your next “clock off” destination?

When: From now until Sunday, August 10, 2025

Where: “Union Station Patio”, Union Station, 65 Front Street West, Toronto

Come dance Ballroom & Latin with us at 30-Up Club on Friday & Saturday

Learn the steps to popular Ballroom, Latin, Social and Line dances for FREE on Friday or Saturday evenings with a wonderful group of regular dancers.

Come dance with us at the 30-Up Club - Toronto's favourite destination for Ballroom and Latin dancing for more than 75 years.

The evening starts with a FREE lesson.

However, you can also pay admission to the club ($28) and stay and dance until midnight to music provided by our excellent and enthusiastic DJs on a large unobstructed maple-wood dance floor. Come as couples or singles and enjoy a light buffet dinner. Dance hosts available to dance with single ladies throughout the evening. Alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks are available at the cash bar all evening.

Most importantly you will spend your evening with lots of great people who share your love of dance.

Cypher Playground Festival

Cypher Playground celebrates club culture. presenting the voices and movements that have defined Toronto’s street dance scene past and present, club history, and underground spaces that fueled its evolution.

This four-day street dance festival includes an opening night with panel discussion on Toronto club history and film screening, a Hustle lesson and Disco/Funk Styles session, and dance battles in the styles of Breaking, House, Punking/Whacking/Waacking, and Popping.

Join us in exploring the roots of local street dance culture, and connect and exchange across dance styles and musical genres.

Tickets available at https://theatrecentre.org/event/cypher-playground-festival/

Follow @cypherplayground on Instagram for updates

Downtown Movies in the Park in Partnership with TIFF's 50th Edition

The Toronto Downtown West BIA is thrilled to announce Downtown Movies in the Park in Partnership with TIFF, a beloved summer tradition, and now bigger than ever in celebration of TIFF’s 50th anniversary.

Every Wednesday night from July 9 to August 13, stretch out under the stars in David Pecaut Square (beside Roy Thomson Hall) for six FREE outdoor screenings hand-picked by TIFF CEO, Cameron Bailey.

Each evening kicks off at 8:45 p.m. with a pre-show featuring live performances, photo ops, film introductions and other outdoor activities. Movie goers can purchase concessions including TIFF’s “famous popcorn”, cold beverages, sweets and cotton candy. Bring your blankets, lawn chairs, and your cinephile crew, and settle in for some big screen magic in the heart of downtown Toronto.

Here are the details:

Film Lineup:

July 9 - The Princess Bride (Directed by Rob Reiner, TIFF ‘87)

Pre-show - a live performance by Hit & Run Productions, featuring a trio of dancers bringing beloved movie characters to life, followed by remarks and an introduction from Cameron Bailey.

July 16 - That Thing You Do (Directed by Tom Hanks, TIFF ‘96)

Pre-show - a themed trivia contest with the chance to win hundreds of dollars in prizes.

July 23 - Beans (Directed by Tracey Deer, TIFF ‘20)

Pre-show - a traditional hoop dance by a solo dancer from the Mohawk Nation, presented by Hit & Run Productions, and an introduction by Kelly Boutsalis, TIFF International Programmer.

July 30 - The Wild Robot (Directed by Chris Sanders, TIFF ‘24)

Pre-show - family-friendly movie trivia and the chance to win exciting prizes.

August 6 - The Martian (Directed by Ridley Scott, TIFF ‘15)

Pre-show - a themed trivia contest and a booth by Space Place Canada, plus an introduction by Cameron Bailey.

August 13 - School of Rock (Directed by Richard Linklater, TIFF ‘03)

Pre-show - a live performance by past and present Battle of the Scores bands, and opens with the winning short from the 48 Hour Film Challenge and an introduction by TIFF’s Next Wave Committee.

When:

Wednesdays, July 9 to August 13

8:45 p.m. – Pre-show fun

9:30 p.m. – Film screening

Where:

David Pecaut Square (215 King St. W., Toronto - beside Roy Thomson Hall)

Accessibility:

All screenings will include open captions.

Launch Party:

Get in the movie mood early on July 9 at the Todotoronto Pre-Party at The Pint Public House (277 Front Street West), featuring trivia, glow sticks, icebreakers, and more. It’s a fun, low-pressure way to meet some new movie pals before the screening. Tickets are required. Doors open at 6:00 p.m.

Emo Night North

As Canada’s longest-running emo night, this event sells out every single week, pulling in a crowd of nostalgic scene kids and new-wave punks. Expect wall-to-wall bangers from the golden era of emo, pop-punk, and post-hardcore: MCR, Paramore, Blink, and all your heartbreak heroes.

Held every Friday at Sneaky Dee’s, the vibe is loud, sweaty, and cathartic — a full-throttle singalong for everyone who still holds a torch for Warped Tour and band tees.

Get there early. Wear black. Scream your heart out.

🖤 Because some nights, emo is everything.

Escape Room Summer Promo!

🔎 Looking for a unique Toronto experience?

Discover one of Toronto’s top rated indoor attractions! At Looking Glass Adventures, you and your team will step into an immersive escape room – a live-action game where you solve puzzles, uncover clues, and complete a thrilling mission before time runs out.

Perfect for families or friends of all ages – no prior experience is needed!

📅 Now with extended summer hours!

💸 Save $10 with promo code SUMMER10

From magical mysteries to epic heists, every adventure is a private, story-driven, and unforgettable experience.

🎟️Book now:

www.lookingglassadventures.com

April 18, 2024 – October 1, 2025

Exhibit A: Investigating Crime & Footwear

This exhibition examines both the development of footwear forensics as a means of solving crime and the social constructions of criminality from the nineteenth century to today. It also considers how clothing and footwear play roles in cultural ideas of criminality informed by assumptions and bias. This exhibition will take visitors on a journey to sleuth out the central but complex role of footwear in crime, policing, the judiciary system and our cultural ideas of criminality.

Curated by:

Dr. Alison Matthews David, Professor at the School of Fashion, Toronto Metropolitan University

Free Senior In Home Support Program- Meals, Friendly Visiting in Scarborough

Heritage Skills Development Centre is excited to extend an invitation to you and your loved ones to our senior in Home Support Program starting January 2024.

This initiative is dedicated to providing meal support, in-home care, friendly visiting and accompaniment to isolated seniors 65+ in the Scarborough community who may be facing challenges.

Our program will support seniors 65+ that are isolated, with disabilities or who are unable to prepare their own meals. Our goal is to enhance the well-being of our seniors.

We are currently seeking clients for this support. If you know a senior that could benefit from this service, please do not hesitate to reach out to us. We are ready to discuss your needs, preferences, and eligibility to ensure you receive the support you deserve.

If you or someone you know is interested in joining our program, please register online through the link below; https://forms.gle/NNJYYARwJi2FEyND7

OR contact us at info@hsdconline.org or call 416-345-1613.

** Proof of age with photo id will be required for approval.

Report Inaccuracy

George Byrne Debuts Synthetica - A Surreal Reimagining of the American Landscape at Bau-Xi Gallery Dufferin

Acclaimed photographic artist George Byrne returns with Synthetica, a bold new exhibition that fuses analogue photography with digital innovation to reimagine the American landscape. Rooted in Byrne’s early influences from the New Topographics movement, this series marks a striking evolution in his practice. Where once he documented, he now deconstructs and rebuilds - layering, subtracting, and collaging until a new reality emerges. The result is a collection of surreal yet grounded dreamscapes, where the ordinary is elevated and the boundaries between the natural and the artificial dissolve. From Daytona Beach to Yellowstone, Synthetica is both a visual journey and a conceptual inquiry - exploring the way we perceive, manipulate, and emotionally respond to our environments in a hyper-mediated, AI-inflected age.

The exhibition will be on view from July 10 - August 4 at Bau-Xi Gallery | Dufferin in Toronto (1384 Dufferin Street). An opening reception will take place on Saturday, July 12 from 2 - 5 pm with George Byrne in attendance.

Artist statement:

“This series explores the tension between the natural and the artificial, challenging preconceptions of reality in an increasingly digital age, while also paying homage to my analogue photographic roots. Starting out as an artist, I was very much a student of the New Topographics photographic movement, a style based on the artist's neutral eye, famous for documenting the mundane structures of post-war America. About 5 years ago, I started to become interested in employing various forms of manipulation and digital reconstruction into the work I was making. As a result, the images were able to become more expressive and introspective; a bridge between my subconscious and conscious. Each image in the Synthetica series started as a medium format film photograph, then, through a process of addition, subtraction, collage and endless reevaluation, a new completed image is born. The foundation of a lot of the images in this series were taken over the last few years during road trips I took around the United States. From Daytona Beach to Yellowstone National Park, these were both natural and man-made landscapes - places I'd never been.” – George Byrne

About George Byrne:

George Byrne is an internationally recognized photographer based in Los Angeles. Byrne creates large-scale photographs that depict architectural surfaces and landscapes as painterly abstractions. Borrowing from the clean, vivid clarity of modernist painting, he also references the New Topographics photography movement via a subject matter firmly entrenched in the urban everyday.

Byrne started photographing Los Angeles with a medium format camera in 2010. Byrne’s close-crop photos, often taken from the middle of the street, show careful attention to the geometric fragments of his urban surroundings revealed in subtle line and unexpected shadow which cut across pastel walled surfaces, and divide soft sky from gritty stucco, plastic and concrete. Byrne’s work encapsulates not only the spirit of his adopted city’s unique and diverse cityscape but an aesthetic sensibility that has come to be ubiquitous with our globalized visual culture influenced by equal parts art history and Instagram.

George Byrne was born in Sydney, Australia in 1976 and graduated from Sydney College of the Arts in 2001. He has exhibited internationally in Italy, India, Australia, Los Angeles, and New York. In 2019, Byrne placed third in the Fine Art category of the Minimalist Photography Awards and was named the Minimalist Photographer of the Year in the Minimalist Photography Awards' 2020 edition. Byrne relocated to Los Angeles, California in 2010, where he continues to live and work.

Ghosts of the Sea

One of the most talked about Canadian films at Hot Docs 2025 returns for its Toronto theatrical premiere.

Until the age of two, Virginia Tangvald lived an unconventional life, sailing the world with her mother, her brother Thomas, and their renowned sailor father, the Norwegian adventurer Peter Tangvald. Years after her father’s death, now a mother herself, Tangvald pieces together the fragments of her family’s story and uncovers a chilling series of events, through which she confronts her now-infamous father’s complex legacy. Haunted by his story and the mysterious death of her beloved brother Thomas, she revisits family friends and an extensive family archive to connect the dots. As the film’s prologue states, Aristotle once said: “There are three kinds of people: the living, the dead and those who go to sea.” Tangvald embraces this sentiment and stylistically infuses her film with an air of the in-between, as her dreamy, melancholic voice leads us through this dark family tale. - Aisha Jamal, Hot Docs

In English and French, with English subtitles.

Ghosts of the Sea - Screenings

The National Film Board of Canada is proud to present the Toronto Theatrical Release of GHOSTS OF THE SEA. A film by Virginia Tangvald.

While searching for clues about the death of her brother, who was lost at sea, Virginia Tangvald embarks on a fascinating investigation into her family’s dark secrets. Calling into question the idyllic life of her father, legendary sailor Peter Tangvald, her quest dismantles the myth of absolute freedom and offers the hope that a toxic cycle has been broken.

Graffiti Alley Outdoor Pottery Workshops All Summer Long!

Clay With Me Presents: Outdoor Pottery in Graffiti Alley – Every Weekend All Summer Long in the heart of the city!

Join us Friday through Sunday for an unforgettable afternoon of creativity, connection, and clay at Clay With Me Pottery Studio!

We’re taking our wheels and hand-building tools outside to the iconic Graffiti Alley—right behind our studio at 474 Richmond St. W. in Toronto. Surrounded by vibrant street art and sunshine, this unique outdoor experience brings together community, creativity, and culture in the heart of the city.

Open to all ages and skill levels

Walk-ins welcome – no experience needed

Mosaic, Paint your own pottery and Wheel classes!

Perfect for dates, friends, or family fun

Let’s get messy, make art, and celebrate summer—one pot at a time.

See you in the alley!

Happy Hour at Gladstone House!

We’re excited to share that Gladstone House has launched Happy Hour menu available every day from 4 p.m - 6 p.m..

The thoughtfully curated menu offers a selection of elevated small plates and timeless drinks. The menu includes freshly shucked oysters with house-made hot sauce, smoked trout dip with saltines, flatbread topped with pomodoro and stracciatella, and a dry-aged burger finished with gruyere and Marie Rose sauce. Guests can sip on house wine, Peroni on draught, an Aperol

Whether you're planning a casual catch-up or a relaxed post-work hangout, Gladstone House offers the perfect setting and bites to match!

Harbourfront Farmers Market

Every Saturday, enjoy the best in seasonal produce, meats and products with Ontario's farmers and small-batch producers. The Harbourfront Farmers Market is a celebration of local agriculture and fresh, homegrown produce. With a strong emphasis on “Grown Here,” this market connects visitors directly with farmers, showcasing the best in season, from farm-fresh eggs and locally-raised meats to artisanal baked goods, preserves and jams, sustainable seafood, handmade pastas and specialty coffee. Experience the freshest flavours while supporting Ontario’s hardworking farmers and small-batch producers.

May 21 – October 12, 2025

Home Game: Toronto Loves Basketball

Home Game: Toronto Loves Basketball chronicles the love story between a city and a sport. Even before the Toronto Raptors and the rallying cry “We the North”, basketball in Toronto was deeply rooted in the evolving social and cultural conditions of our city and its people.

From the Canadian invention of basketball to the early women’s game in 1895, to the first professional game played by the Toronto Huskies in 1946, and the recent creation of the Toronto Tempo WNBA team, these milestones chart the development of the sport in our city.

This exhibition, along with a series of profiles on fellow Torontonians, explores how the relationship between basketball and Toronto is unlike any other in the world.

Home Game App: Museum of Toronto has partnered with Dr. Sarah Bay-Cheng, Prof. Angela Norwood and her students in the Design Lab at York University to develop an app that will bring basketball history to life via augmented reality.

Through the app you can custom design your own basketball jersey and view contemporary and historical game-related objects, including the first Toronto Huskies game ticket and Scarborough Shooting Stars trophy.

In addition to an app entry portal at Harbourfront Centre, three off-site activations will be connected via the Home Game app and will allow fans to learn more about Toronto’s basketball history and share their basketball memories through the app’s AR experience, including:

Pan Am Centre

York University, Vari Hall

Regent Park Community Centre

TICKETS

Admission is free, donations are encouraged.

No reservation required.

LOCATION

Harbourfront Centre, 225 Queens Quay West

HOURS

Wednesday, Thursday: 12:00 PM – 6:00 PM

Friday: 12:00 PM – 8:00 PM

Saturday: 10:00 AM – 8:00 PM

Sunday: 12:00 PM – 7:00 PM

Hope Letter Campaign

An educational online activity that teaches children in Canada about global issues in a fun way! The Hope Letter Campaign is a letter-writing contest for children of all ages.

They will start by learning about the importance of clean water through a case study video by Good Neighbours Canada. Based on this, your child can reflect on what they learned and write a Letter of Hope to the child in the video. Letters can be uploaded on our website or mailed to us for a chance to win a $300 donation in your child's name and a goodie bag from our social enterprise shop, Goods4Causes.

Children of all ages can join. Parent's consent is needed to join the contest. Send your letters by August 31, 2025 to be part of the contest. Winners will be contacted through the contact info they provided in their letters.

Jessica Stockholder: The Squared Circle: Ringing

MOCA is thrilled to present a major new commission by the groundbreaking American-Canadian artist Jessica Stockholder, “The Squared Circle: Ringing.”

This spring, visitors on Floor 1 are invited to experience a new large-scale, site-specific artwork by Stockholder, alongside a series of text-based gestures. Revisiting elements from her 2021 installation “Cut a rug a round square,” Stockholder will further explore the interplay between material, colour, and perspective to transform the space into an immersive experience. Incorporating poetic writing into her practice, she will engage with the museum’s various messages, altering and interrupting them to shift viewers’ attention toward the formal beauty and complexity of language.

Often referred to as “paintings in space,” Stockholder’s work resists easy categorization, existing at the intersection of abstract expressionism, colour field painting, minimalism, and theatre.

Justin Ming Yong: Blur

Experience “Blur,” an exciting site-specific project by Toronto-based textile artist Justin Ming Yong, whose handmade quilts will transform the North End Gallery and the museum’s elevators into immersive art spaces.

Yong has developed a textile practice that reinterprets traditional quilt-making—a craft passed down to him by his mother, an avid quilt-maker. This practice, rooted in centuries-old cultural traditions, explores the interplay of colour, pattern, and geometry. His works, crafted from diverse materials and layered prints, balance harmony and tension, resulting in abstract compositions that are both gestural and hard-edged.

Immerse yourself in “Blur” at MOCA and see how Yong’s vibrant quilts reshape familiar spaces.

May 29 – August 17, 2025
Report Inaccuracy

Koffler Arts Presents Elinor Carucci & Hannah Altman

Koffler Arts is excited to welcome photographers Elinor Carucci and Hannah Altman to our gallery for an exhibition (May 29 - August 17), curated by Toronto-based artist Barbara Astman. The exhibition highlights the unique dynamic that exists between each artist's practice and their different life stages, exploring life from a Jewish feminist perspective, including womanhood, rituals, family, and the human condition.

Carucci’s works at Koffler Arts are a selection from Midlife (2011-2019), a photographic series and corresponding book (The Monacelli Press, 2019) never previously exhibited in its present format.

Altman’s work explores themes of ritual and lineage, memory and storytelling, incorporating aspects of Jewish culture. The works at Koffler Arts are from her most recent series, We Will Return To You, with a corresponding book (Saint Lucy Books, 2025).

As Astman writes, she, Carucci, and Altman “represent collectively three generations of image-makers who explore life from a feminist perspective. It has been an honour and pleasure to ‘dig deeper’ – to quote Carucci from an interview with Altman – into the work and careers of these two very exciting artists who bring a highly personal Jewish approach to their photographic works.”

Kour Pour: Cosmic Diagrams

On display in the Aga Khan Museum, Kour Pour: Cosmic Diagrams showcases three monumental paintings that explore the kaleidoscopic ways in which different cultures have envisioned the cosmos. Inspired by celestial and terrestrial designs from diverse artistic traditions, and blending elements of Persian carpets, mandalas, and zodiacal charts, these works reveal a shared quest to understand a vast, interconnected cosmic order.

LEGO Summer of Play at LEGOLAND Discovery Centre Toronto

This summer, get ready for a celebration of play like no other at LEGOLAND Discovery Centre Toronto. LEGO® Summer of Play is packed with awesome activities that help kids discover their unique Play Mode – whether they love to create, discover, build, dance or simply play their own way.

Families can learn how to create a LEGO bee and design a playful city with the Master Model Builder where their imaginations can run wild. Kids of all ages can boogie to the DJ GoodVibes dance party, and then have fun spotting surprise LEGO creations in MINILAND which has Toronto's cityscape created out of more than 1.5 million LEGO bricks.

Event Highlights:

- Imagine and design a more playful city in our Creative Workshop with a Master Model Builder

- Spot the summer surprises hidden in MINILAND

- Join a FESTIVAL dance party with an awesome LEGO character

- Build a LEGO bee and display in on our LEGO flower cart

- Capture your Play Mode pose in a photo with a LEGO character and share the moment

Making a Museum - The Photographic Exhibition

What’s in a photograph? A moment in time, caught between light and memory — a story waiting to be told. Photography preserves the feeling of a moment, not just its details. Unlike an artifact, a photograph offers a small window into the past, inviting us to imagine the lives unfolding just beyond the frame.

At the Ukrainian Museum of Canada – Ontario Branch, several boxes of vintage 35mm slides were uncovered during the development of a recent exhibition. This remarkable collection captures the people — volunteers, artists, visitors, and community members — whose care, creativity, and commitment helped shape the Museum across generations.

Each image offers an intimate connection to the past, deserving a space where every face can be seen and every moment remembered — a quiet tribute to the legacy of the Museum and the many hands and hearts that built it over the past 80 years.

On view until August 22, 2025, Making a Museum: The Photographic Exhibition invites visitors to linger in memory — to see not just the faces of the past, but the spirit that continues to shape the present.

July 18 - August 22, 2025

Margaux Williamson: Shoes, books, hands, buildings, and cars

Margaux Williamson paints scenes drawing from the intimate views and objects of her home, studio, bars, city streets, and the natural world around her. Her muted colour palette and ethereal brushwork, combined with contrasting perspectives, evoke the sensation of memories and dreams.

MOCA is pleased to present a solo exhibition featuring several new and recent paintings by the artist on Floor 3 of the museum. “Shoes, books, hands, buildings,” and cars highlights the evolution of Williamson’s painting practice, which has grown in both complexity and scale.

Visit MOCA to experience Williamson’s evocative paintings up close.

MOCA Toronto Hours

Morning Yoga @ Soulpepper Theatre

Start your day with some morning yoga to gently wake up your body, breath, and senses. Each class will explore some meditation, pranayama (breathwork), and other grounding techniques for the nervous system, as well as move through some movement and stretches to gently energise the body.

Suitable for all levels including beginners. Seated, standing and lying down poses will be included with different options and students are encouraged to find and choose what works best for them.

Please bring your own mat.
